Award.AwardTitle: Support for Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
ThisThis project provides funding for travel support for U.S. researchers and students to attend a workshop on "Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes" to be held in Austin, Texas, in early May of 2017. The workshop builds on a successful workshop on this topic held in 2015. Analog model experiments contribute substantially to the understanding of tectonic processes. In these experiments, weaker materials (sand, clay, etc.) take the place rocks and are deformed at high strain rates under controlled conditions thus producing scale models of the development of earth structures (faults, folds) and large-scale tectonic features (mountain belts, rift systems). The aim of this workshop is to bring together the tectonics analog modeling community to discuss future directions in the field, build collaborations with computer-based modelers, and develop curriculum materials. The workshop participants include experimentalists, computer modelers, students, and instructors who use analog models in their classrooms. The workshop will promote the analog modeling skills of early career researchers, thereby developing the future workforce in tectonics. The workshop will promote the participation of students, early career scientists, and researchers from underrepresented groups in the earth sciences.

The past 10 years have seen a revolution within analog modeling of crustal deformation spurred by systematic rheological testing of analog materials and use of laser and image processing techniques for data analysis leading to a strengthening of the quantitative aspect of analog modeling. The vanguard of this revolution has been in Europe where laboratories have been implementing new approaches that permit greater control on experimental conditions, more accurate scaling of deformation and improved insights into the evolution of deformation and deformation processes. This multi-day workshop gathers leading US and international geoscientists who use analog and numerical modeling to discuss techniques that are revolutionizing experimental modeling, as well as challenges for performing and analyzing scaled experiments. This workshop provides a unique and largely informal opportunity for researchers to share some of their best practices. As a mechanism to foster idea-sharing, a half-day physical experiment followed by a half-day numerical analysis will be performed to encourage the entire group to engage in experimental set-up, trouble shooting, data gathering and analysis and to sensitize each community to the needs of the other. Curriculum material developed for the workshop will be freely available through the Science Education Resource Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Analog or physical models provide researchers and teachers with a powerful approach to understanding deformation and tectonics because it can be continuously and quantitatively documented under controlled conditions. Furthermore experiments provide reliable testing grounds for numerical experiments. Although analog models contribute substantially to the development of new tectonic concepts, benchmarks of numerical models, and interactive teaching, the US analog modeling community is dispersed and small. The aim of this NSF funded workshop was to strengthen the US based analog-modeling community and bring it closer together with the numerical-modeling community to discuss exciting innovations, benchmarking possibilities, novel science curriculum materials, and to learn from each other. The workshop was held at the University of Texas at Austin from May 17 to 19, 2017.  It was attended by 48 participants who were analog experimentalists, numerical modelers that need experimental results to further their research, students, postdocs, instructors who use analog models in their classrooms, and researchers who are interested in comparing their observations to results of analog experiments. The workshop has provided a unique and largely informal opportunity for all participants to share some of their best practices. As a mechanism to foster idea-sharing, a physical experiment followed by a numerical analysis of the same problem was performed during the workshop. This lead to lively discussions on experimental set-up, trouble shooting, data gathering and analysis. Furthermore it sensitized both the experimentalists and numerical modelers to the needs of the other community.

Besides the hands-on experience ten oral presentations were given by invited speakers and almost all workshop participants presented their work in poster format. Three examples of how to incorporate experiments into the classroom were showcased during the workshop. Use of authentic analog models in classrooms can foster critical thinking skills and promote the use of experiments to a wider community. The presented classroom activities have been made available through the SERC webpage.

By incorporating and paying travel support for participants who were graduate students and post-doctoral scholars, the workshop was able to promote the involvement of early career researchers.  By adding analog and numerical modeling skills to their research toolbox, these researchers will be better equipped to perform experiments and/or utilize analog modeling results to address future research questions. A small part of the awarded money was used to support ten students to visit a US based analog modeling laboratory of their choosing to conduct experiments and learn about new techniques first-hand.

This award supported the second analog modeling of tectonic processes workshop. This is the only workshop series that is specifically for analog modelers in the US and thereby plays an essential role in strengthening this community. The workshop was able to expand on the positive outcome of the first analog modeling workshop at University of Massachusetts - Amherst in 2015 and expanded its focus to include members of the numerical modeling community. Due to the small size of the workshop there was a vivid exchange of ideas throughout the duration of the workshop. The atmosphere during the three days at the University of Texas was lively and positive with many great discussions across research fields and backgrounds and levels of expertise. New applications for models and materials were discovered, practical help offered and problems solved.

 A workshop report has been published in EOS (Reber et al., 2017).
